trans-unit.source: To perform an operation on a resource (app, logical number, group, etc), a HTTP request is made to the URL using the appropriate HTTP verb.

seg-source.mrk: To perform an operation on a resource (app, logical number, group, etc), a HTTP request is made to the URL using the appropriate HTTP verb.

target.mrk: To perform an operation on a resource (app, logical number, group, etc), a HTTP request is made to the URL using the appropriate HTTP verb.

trans-unit.source: The four HTTP verbs used in CRUD operations are:

seg-source.mrk: The four HTTP verbs used in CRUD operations are:

target.mrk: The four HTTP verbs used in CRUD operations are:

trans-unit.source: GET: Finds a specific resource or collection of resources from an URL. For example, GET /%{version}/devices returns a list with all serial numbers, while a GET /%{version}/devices/135 returns only the serial number with the ID 135.

seg-source.mrk: GET: Finds a specific resource or collection of resources from an URL.
For example, GET /%{version}/devices returns a list with all serial numbers, while a GET /%{version}/devices/135 returns only the serial number with the ID 135.

target.mrk: GET: Finds a specific resource or collection of resources from an URL.
For example, GET /%{version}/devices returns a list with all serial numbers, while a GET /%{version}/devices/135 returns only the serial number with the ID 135.

trans-unit.source: POST: Creates a new resource. For example, POST /%{version}/devices creates a new serial number. The information sent in the POST request would then be used to fill the properties of the serial number.

seg-source.mrk: POST: Creates a new resource.
For example, POST /%{version}/devices creates a new serial number.
The information sent in the POST request would then be used to fill the properties of the serial number.

target.mrk: POST: Creates a new resource.
For example, POST /%{version}/devices creates a new serial number.
The information sent in the POST request would then be used to fill the properties of the serial number.

trans-unit.source: PUT: Updates an existing resource. For example, PUT /%{version}/devices/135 updates the serial number with the ID 135. The information sent in the PUT request would then be used to update the properties of the serial number.

seg-source.mrk: PUT: Updates an existing resource.
For example, PUT /%{version}/devices/135 updates the serial number with the ID 135.
The information sent in the PUT request would then be used to update the properties of the serial number.

target.mrk: PUT: Updates an existing resource.
For example, PUT /%{version}/devices/135 updates the serial number with the ID 135.
The information sent in the PUT request would then be used to update the properties of the serial number.

trans-unit.source: DELETE: Deletes an existing resource. For example, DELETE /%{version}/devices/135 deletes the serial number with the ID 135.

seg-source.mrk: DELETE: Deletes an existing resource.
For example, DELETE /%{version}/devices/135 deletes the serial number with the ID 135.

target.mrk: DELETE: Deletes an existing resource.
For example, DELETE /%{version}/devices/135 deletes the serial number with the ID 135.

trans-unit.source: Requests that return multiple records are paginated, where the default pagination size is 30 records. The sub-sequent pages are defined by the parameter &page. The default amount of returned records can be changed by defining the parameter &per_page, up to 100 records.

trans-unit.source: The CloudWalk Switch will receive the request sent through the command network.send and will perform the HTTP request on the url defined on the application configured on https://manager.cloudwalk.io.

seg-source.mrk: The CloudWalk Switch will receive the request sent through the command network.send and will perform the HTTP request on the url defined on the application configured on https://manager.cloudwalk.io.

target.mrk: The CloudWalk Switch will receive the request sent through the command network.send and will perform the HTTP request on the url defined on the application configured on https://manager.cloudwalk.io.

trans-unit.source: To receive the answer from CloudWalk Switch, it is necessary to use the command network.receive to receive the first 4 bytes that indicates the size of the message, and then receive the rest of the message with a second network.receive call. This approach avoid timeouts and long wait times to receive the response from your HTTP endpoint.

seg-source.mrk: To receive the answer from CloudWalk Switch, it is necessary to use the command network.receive to receive the first 4 bytes that indicates the size of the message, and then receive the rest of the message with a second network.receive call.
This approach avoid timeouts and long wait times to receive the response from your HTTP endpoint.

target.mrk: To receive the answer from CloudWalk Switch, it is necessary to use the command network.receive to receive the first 4 bytes that indicates the size of the message, and then receive the rest of the message with a second network.receive call.

trans-unit.source: CloudWalk is a SaaS based application platform for devices such as POS terminals and smartphones. The service offers hardware agnostic solution, which allows any application developed with CloudWalk to be compatible with all approved devices, offering many benefits, such as EMV and contactless technology.

trans-unit.source: POSXML is a name given to the programming language created by Plano Bê, aimed at developing applications for devices such as POS terminals and smartphones. It is organized and structured in the form of tags, showing levels and subsets of a set of commands and instructions, which form the logical structure of a POSXML application.

seg-source.mrk: POSXML is a name given to the programming language created by Plano Bê, aimed at developing applications for devices such as POS terminals and smartphones.
It is organized and structured in the form of tags, showing levels and subsets of a set of commands and instructions, which form the logical structure of a POSXML application.

target.mrk: POSXML is a name given to the programming language created by Plano Bê, aimed at developing applications for devices such as POS terminals and smartphones.
It is organized and structured in the form of tags, showing levels and subsets of a set of commands and instructions, which form the logical structure of a POSXML application.

trans-unit.source: Structured and based on XML (acronym for eXtensible Markup Language), POSXML is easy to learn, has mathematical features and powerful graphical capabilities that enable the creation of animated interfaces with icons and animations.

seg-source.mrk: Structured and based on XML (acronym for eXtensible Markup Language), POSXML is easy to learn, has mathematical features and powerful graphical capabilities that enable the creation of animated interfaces with icons and animations.

variablereturn [integer]

  • 0: OK
  • 11: Invalid parameter passed on emv.adddata
  • 12: Timeout
  • 13: Insert, card swipe or choose application operation canceled by the user
  • 15: Library EMV not initiated
  • 16: Internal error
  • 20: Device timestamp doesn't match with the parameter's timestamp passed through emv.adddata
  • 40: Execution error
  • 41: Error while reading the card
  • 43: Card removed in the middle of the operation

trans-unit.source: The command emv.inittransaction begins processing the EMV card, either magnetic stripe or chip. At this time, the EMV library will ask the card insertion/swipe in order to choose and start the EMV application on the smartcard. The answer is the card data to be analyzed by the device application.

seg-source.mrk: The command emv.inittransaction begins processing the EMV card, either magnetic stripe or chip.
At this time, the EMV library will ask the card insertion/swipe in order to choose and start the EMV application on the smartcard.
The answer is the card data to be analyzed by the device application.

target.mrk: The command emv.inittransaction begins processing the EMV card, either magnetic stripe or chip.
At this time, the EMV library will ask the card insertion/swipe in order to choose and start the EMV application on the smartcard.
The answer is the card data to be analyzed by the device application.

trans-unit.source:
In the example above, there are three conditions:
  • 1st - compares two texts causing it to be true as Blue is equal to the value of the variable sColor
  • 2nd - compares two numbers causing it to be false as 111 is not greater than the value of the variable iNumber
  • 3rd - compares two texts causing it to be false as Blue is different from the value of the variable sColor. POSXML considers uppercase and lowercase letters (case-sensitive)
The command waitkey awaits a click of any key to continue code execution.

  • 3rd - compares two texts causing it to be false as Blue is different from the value of the variable sColor.

trans-unit.source: In the above example, after starting the ISO8583 message through the command iso8583.initmessage and inserting the fields through the command iso8583.putfield according to the bitmap (bitmap.dat), the command iso8583.endmessage will be responsible to finish the message, storing on the variable iSizeMessageISO the message size and also storing the complete message on the variable sMsgIso8583.

ASCII: 4 ASCII bytes (x30 x32 x35 x36 or 0256)

trans-unit.source: In the above example, there are three operations: difference, sum and less.

seg-source.mrk: In the above example, there are three operations: difference, sum and less.

target.mrk: In the above example, there are three operations: difference, sum and less.

trans-unit.source: The first operation done is the difference, where the content of the variable sDate1 is compared with the content of the variable sDate2, and the difference between them is returned in seconds and stored on variablereturn.

seg-source.mrk: The first operation done is the difference, where the content of the variable sDate1 is compared with the content of the variable sDate2, and the difference between them is returned in seconds and stored on variablereturn.

target.mrk: The first operation done is the difference, where the content of the variable sDate1 is compared with the content of the variable sDate2, and the difference between them is returned in seconds and stored on variablereturn.

trans-unit.source: The second operation done is sum, where 10 hours is added on the date stored on sDate1. If the operation is successfully executed, the variable variablereturn receive 0, and the date stored on sDate1 will be increased by 10 hours.

seg-source.mrk: The second operation done is sum, where 10 hours is added on the date stored on sDate1.
If the operation is successfully executed, the variable variablereturn receive 0, and the date stored on sDate1 will be increased by 10 hours.

target.mrk: The second operation done is sum, where 10 hours is added on the date stored on sDate1.
If the operation is successfully executed, the variable variablereturn receive 0, and the date stored on sDate1 will be increased by 10 hours.

trans-unit.source: The third operation done is less, where 10 minutes is subtracted from the date stored on sDate1. If the operation is successfully executed, the variable variablereturn receive 0, and the date stored on sDate1 will be decreased by 10 minutes.

seg-source.mrk: The third operation done is less, where 10 minutes is subtracted from the date stored on sDate1.
If the operation is successfully executed, the variable variablereturn receive 0, and the date stored on sDate1 will be decreased by 10 minutes.

trans-unit.source:
In the example above, there are three conditions:
  • 1st - compare two texts causing it to be true as Blue is equal to the value of the variable sColor
  • 2nd - compare two numbers causing it to be false as 111 is not greater than the value of the variable iNumber
  • 3rd - compare two texts is causing it false as Blue is different from the value of the variable sColor. POSXML considers uppercase and lowercase letters (case-sensitive)
The command waitkey awaits click any key to continue code execution.

trans-unit.source: The POSXML has the concept of variable types, where they can be of type string or integer. Limitations and parameter passing.

Limitations and parameter passing.

trans-unit.source: The WALK Framework is responsible for running compiled POSXML application, and being installed on the device, assumes all responsibility for memory management and devices. Thus, to run an application on the device, just write a file in POSXML, compile it and send it to the device.

seg-source.mrk: The WALK Framework is responsible for running compiled POSXML application, and being installed on the device, assumes all responsibility for memory management and devices.
Thus, to run an application on the device, just write a file in POSXML, compile it and send it to the device.

target.mrk: The WALK Framework is responsible for running compiled POSXML application, and being installed on the device, assumes all responsibility for memory management and devices.
Thus, to run an application on the device, just write a file in POSXML, compile it and send it to the device.

trans-unit.source: There is a limit of 511 variables per POSXML application, and 256 of type string with maximum size of 1K (1023 characters, of which one is used automatically by the platform to allocate the \0), and 255 of type integer.

trans-unit.source: When you declare a variable with the commands integervariable or stringvariable, it will be in memory of the application until the device is disconnected. For this reason, you must be careful to define on the beginning of the application all variables used and clean them for no errors occur during the execution of the application.

trans-unit.source: It is possible to add parameters to a group. For example, the group AREA 51 has several logical numbers and sales application. This group then has a parameter called SPECIAL_TICKET, with the value 1. Thus, all devices belonging to this group inherit this parameter.

seg-source.mrk: It is possible to add parameters to a group.
For example, the group AREA 51 has several logical numbers and sales application.
This group then has a parameter called SPECIAL_TICKET, with the value 1.
Thus, all devices belonging to this group inherit this parameter.

target.mrk: It is possible to add parameters to a group.
For example, the group AREA 51 has several logical numbers and sales application.
This group then has a parameter called SPECIAL_TICKET, with the value 1.
Thus, all devices belonging to this group inherit this parameter.

trans-unit.source: Logic of sales application makes a validation on the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET, and since value is 1, the application prints a special ticket, with additional company information for purposes of disclosure.

seg-source.mrk: Logic of sales application makes a validation on the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET, and since value is 1, the application prints a special ticket, with additional company information for purposes of disclosure.

target.mrk: Logic of sales application makes a validation on the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET, and since value is 1, the application prints a special ticket, with additional company information for purposes of disclosure.

trans-unit.source: After long analysis by the strategic team, they came to the conclusion that the cost of printing this special, more detailed ticket, is not worth it. Analysts then decided to change the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET value from 1 to 0. Ready! Now all devices belonging to the group AREA 51 will no longer print the special tickets.

seg-source.mrk: After long analysis by the strategic team, they came to the conclusion that the cost of printing this special, more detailed ticket, is not worth it.
Analysts then decided to change the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET value from 1 to 0.
Ready! Now all devices belonging to the group AREA 51 will no longer print the special tickets.

target.mrk: After long analysis by the strategic team, they came to the conclusion that the cost of printing this special, more detailed ticket, is not worth it.
Analysts then decided to change the parameter SPECIAL_TICKET value from 1 to 0.
Ready! Now all devices belonging to the group AREA 51 will no longer print the special tickets.

trans-unit.source: You can add parameters to a logical number. For example, the logical number 100022 is used on the device on restaurant 'Chop Suey' of Mr. Li Hanzo. This logical number then has a parameter called NUM_PARCELS, with the value 1.

seg-source.mrk: You can add parameters to a logical number.
For example, the logical number 100022 is used on the device on restaurant 'Chop Suey' of Mr. Li Hanzo.
This logical number then has a parameter called NUM_PARCELS, with the value 1.

target.mrk: You can add parameters to a logical number.
For example, the logical number 100022 is used on the device on restaurant 'Chop Suey' of Mr. Li Hanzo.
This logical number then has a parameter called NUM_PARCELS, with the value 1.

trans-unit.source: Logic of the sales application makes a validation on the parameter NUM_PARCELS, and since the value is 1, the application offers only the payment option 'on cash'.

seg-source.mrk: Logic of the sales application makes a validation on the parameter NUM_PARCELS, and since the value is 1, the application offers only the payment option 'on cash'.

target.mrk: Logic of the sales application makes a validation on the parameter NUM_PARCELS, and since the value is 1, the application offers only the payment option 'on cash'.

trans-unit.source: The restaurant of Mr. Li, presenting excellent results, drew the attention of the strategic team of restaurants 'Chop Suey', and they decided to offer the possibility to Mr. Li to accept payment in installments. For this change, it is enough that someone from strategic staff alter the parameter NUM_PARCELS value from 1 to 3. Ready!
